{{EngvarB|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox election | election_name = Witney by-election, 2016 | type = parliamentary | country = United Kingdom | seats_for_election = [[Witney (UK Parliament constituency)|Witney]] constituency | ongoing = no | previous_election = United Kingdom general election, 2015 | previous_year = 2015 | next_election = United Kingdom general election, 2017 | next_year = 2017 | election_date = 20 October 2016 | monarch = [[Elizabeth II]] | primeminister1 = [[Theresa May]] | candidate1 = '''[[Robert Courts]]''' | image1 = [[File:Official portrait of Robert Courts crop 2.jpg|150x150px]] | party1 = Conservative Party (UK) | last_election1 = | popular_vote1 = '''17,313''' | percentage1 = '''45.0%''' | swing1 = {{decrease}}15.2% | candidate2 = Liz Leffman | image2 =[[File:No image.svg|110x110px]] | party2 = Liberal Democrats (UK) | last_election2 = | popular_vote2 = 11,611 | percentage2 = 30.2% | swing2 = {{increase}}23.4% | candidate3 = Duncan Enright | image3 =[[File:No image.svg|110x110px]] | party3 = Labour Party (UK) | last_election3 = | popular_vote3 = 5,765 | percentage3 = 15.0% | swing3 = {{decrease}}2.2% | map_image = Witney2007Constituency.svg | map_size = 250px | map_caption = Location of [[Witney (UK Parliament constituency)|Witney]] within [[Oxfordshire]] | title = [[Member of Parliament|MP]] | posttitle = | before_election = [[David Cameron]] | before_party = [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] | after_election = [[Robert Courts]] | after_party = [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] }} The '''Witney by-election''' was a [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|UK parliamentary]] by-election held on 20 October 2016 in the [[constituency]] of [[Witney (UK Parliament constituency)|Witney]] in Oxfordshire. It took place on the same day as the [[Batley and Spen by-election, 2016|Batley and Spen by-election]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37371430|title=Batley by-election to be on 20 October|date=15 September 2016|publisher=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=15 September 2016}}</ref> They were the fifth and sixth by-elections of the [[56th Parliament of the United Kingdom|56th UK Parliament]].
The by-election was triggered by the resignation of the sitting Member of Parliament (MP) [[David Cameron]] on 12 September 2016.<ref name="itv">{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/news/2016-09-12/david-cameron-resigns-his-seat-as-an-mp/|publisher=itv.com|title=David Cameron resigns as an MP – ITV News|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201617/cmvote/160912v01.htm |title=House of Commons Votes and Proceedings Monday 12th September 2016 |publisher=Parliament of the United Kingdom |accessdate=26 September 2016}}</ref> The election was won by Conservative [[Robert Courts]] with a reduced majority, and the Liberal Democrats came in second with an increase in vote share of 23.4 percentage points.
==Background== [[David Cameron]] had been the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] MP for the seat since the [[United Kingdom general election, 2001|2001 general election]], becoming leader of the Conservative Party in 2005 and Prime Minister of the United Kingdom in 2010. Following the Leave result in the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|referendum on the United Kingdom's membership of the European Union]] that Cameron had campaigned against, he resigned as Prime Minister and leader of the Conservative Party, being replaced by [[Theresa May]]. In September 2016 he announced his resignation as an MP saying he did not want to be a distraction to May's premiership.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37342152 |title=David Cameron quits as Conservative MP for Witney |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=12 September 2016 |publisher=BBC News |access-date=14 September 2016 }}</ref>
==Candidates== The Conservatives picked Robert Courts, a barrister and West Oxfordshire District Councillor since 2014, from a shortlist of three candidates.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hughes|first1=Laura|title=New Conservative candidate for David Cameron's Witney seat revealed as barrister Robert Courts|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/09/22/new-conservative-candidate-for-david-camerons-witney-seat-reveal/|accessdate=22 September 2016|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=22 September 2016}}</ref> Though Witney voted in favour of remain in the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|EU referendum on 23 June 2016]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Referendum on the United Kingdom's Membership of the European Union|url=http://www.westoxon.gov.uk/media/1436954/EU-Referendum-Result-23-June-2016.pdf|publisher=West Oxfordshire DC|accessdate=13 October 2016}}</ref> Courts is a "Brexiter".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Elgot|first1=Jessica|title=Witney byelection: hard Brexit may be key issue in Cameron's former constituency|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/oct/11/witney-byelection-hard-brexit-may-be-key-issue-in-camerons-former-constituency|accessdate=13 October 2016|work=The Guardian|date=11 October 2016}}</ref>
The Labour Party selected Duncan Enright as their candidate. He serves as a West Oxfordshire District Councillor and stood in Witney at the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 general election]], finishing second behind Cameron.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.labour-southeast.org.uk/duncan_enright_selected_as_labour_s_candidate_for_witney|title=Duncan Enright selected as Labour's candidate for Witney|publisher=Labour South East|date=20 September 2016|accessdate=21 September 2016}}</ref>
The Liberal Democrats selected Liz Leffman, a West Oxfordshire District Councillor (for Charlbury and Finstock) and local businesswoman, as the party's candidate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.markpack.org.uk/143270/liz-leffman-selected-lib-dems-witney/|title=Liz Leffman selected for the Lib Dems in Witney|publisher=Mark Pack|date=20 September 2016|accessdate=21 September 2016}}</ref> She stood in Witney in [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005]], finishing second to Cameron.
The UK Independence Party named Kenrick "Dickie" Bird.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/live/uk-england-oxfordshire-37309991|title=UKIP announce Witney candidate – Oxfordshire Live: Monday 26 September|publisher=BBC News|date=26 September 2016|accessdate=26 September 2016}}</ref> He served in the army in Oxfordshire's local Regiment, [[The Royal Green Jackets]], before becoming Head Porter at [[Oriel College, Oxford]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Head porter at one of Oxford University's oldest colleges quits to run as Ukip MP candidate|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/ukip/11183342/Head-porter-at-one-of-Oxford-Universitys-oldest-colleges-quits-to-run-as-Ukip-MP-candidate.html|accessdate=26 September 2016|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=24 October 2014}}</ref> and stood in [[Banbury (UK Parliament constituency)|Banbury]] in 2015, coming third.<ref>{{cite web|title=Banbury constituency 2015 results|url=http://www.cherwell.gov.uk/index.cfm?articleid=10679|website=Cherwell DC|accessdate=26 September 2016}}</ref>
The Green Party named [[Larry Sanders (politician)|Larry Sanders]], a former Oxfordshire County Councillor and brother of US Senator [[Bernie Sanders]]. He came fifth in the 2015 general election in the neighbouring constituency of [[Oxford West and Abingdon (UK Parliament constituency)|Oxford West and Abingdon]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Tories select barrister for Cameron's Witney seat|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37447086|accessdate=22 September 2016|publisher=BBC News|date=22 September 2016}}</ref>
The [[National Health Action Party]] (NHA) selected Dr Helen Salisbury, an Oxford GP and lecturer at [[Oxford University Medical School]].<ref>http://nhap.org/helen-salisbury/</ref> Salisbury was their candidate in Oxford West & Abingdon at the 2015 general election.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gponline.com/meet-gps-heading-parliament-general-election/article/1346093|title=Meet the GPs heading for parliament after general election|publisher=[[GPOnline.com]]|date=8 May 2015|accessdate=11 October 2016}}</ref>
[[Winston McKenzie]], a former professional boxer and a [[perennial candidate]], has been named as the candidate of the English Democrats.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxfordtimes.co.uk/news/14754069.First_candidate_for_Witney_by_election_announced/|title=Seat left vacant by former PM David Cameron will be contested by Winston McKenzie|work=[[The Oxford Times]]|date=20 September 2016|accessdate=21 September 2016}}</ref> He came third in [[Croydon North (UK Parliament constituency)|Croydon North]] at the previous general election.
Independent candidate Adam Knight endorsed the Liberal Democrat candidate, Leffman, during the campaign.<ref>http://www.libdemvoice.org/rival-candidate-endorses-liz-leffman-for-witney-52096.html</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Alfie Evans | birth_name = Alfie James Evans | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|2016|5|9|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Toxteth]], [[Liverpool]], England | death_date = {{death date|df=yes|2018|04|28}}
(aged {{age for infant|2016|5|9|2018|4|28}}) | death_place = [[West Derby]], Liverpool, England | parents = {{Plainlist| *Thomas Evans *Kate James }} }} The '''Alfie Evans case''' was a [[legal case]] in 2018 involving Alfie Evans (9 May 2016 – 28 April 2018), an infant boy from [[Liverpool]] with an undiagnosed [[Neurodegeneration|neurodegenerative disorder]].{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/04/25/alfie-evanss-father-threatened-private-murder-prosecution-against|title=Alfie Evans's father threatened private murder prosecution against doctors treating the toddler|first=Patrick|last=Sawer|date=25 April 2018|publisher=telegraph.co.uk}} The medical team and the child's parents disagreed about whether to maintain Evans' [[life support]] or to withdraw it, resulting in a legal battle. [[Alder Hey Children's Hospital|Alder Hey Children's NHS Foundation Trust]] sought a declaration that continued [[Mechanical ventilation|ventilatory support]] was "unkind and inhumane", and not in Evans' best interests. Alfie's parents, Kate James and Thomas Evans, contested the application. The ventilatory support was removed on 23 April 2018 following a series of unsuccessful appeals from Alfie's family. Alfie continued to breathe naturally for five days after the removal of his breathing tube. He died at 2:30 a.m. on 28 April 2018. == Treatment == [[File:Alder Hey Children's Health Park 2.jpg|thumb|Alder Hey Children's Hospital, where Alfie Evans was treated from December 2016 until his death.]] In November 2016, at six months of age, Alfie Evans was reviewed at the general pediatric outpatient clinic at [[Alder Hey Children's Hospital]]. He was found to be functioning in a range appropriate for a 6-week to 2-month-old infant. On 14 December 2016, Alfie was admitted to Alder Hey Accident and Emergency Department with a history of coughing, high temperature, and a reported episode of rhythmic jerking of his jaw and all four limbs.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-43933056|title=Legal battle toddler Alfie Evans dies|date=28 April 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}} On 15 December, he showed sudden unprovoked movements compatible with [[Epileptic spasms|infantile/epileptic spasms]]. An [[Electroencephalography|EEG]] performed on 16 December 2016 confirmed [[hypsarrhythmia]].{{cite web|url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/alfie-evans-timeline-legal-battle-14312017|title=Alfie Evans timeline: How one young boy captured the hearts of millions|first=Steve|last=Graves|date=28 April 2018|publisher=}} A further EEG was taken in January 2017 and "was markedly different, showing attenuation with little in the way of reactive response for protracted periods of time. Changes only really occurred when Alfie had an epileptic seizure."{{cite web|url=https://www.judiciary.gov.uk/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/alder-hey-v-evans.pdf|title=Alder Hey Hospital v Evans|publisher=Royal Court of Justice|author=Justice Anthony Hayden|date=20 February 2018|access-date=28 April 2018}} Alfie's parents wished to remove him from Alder Hey and seek further care at the [[Bambino Gesù Hospital]] in [[Rome]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/01/alfie-evans-continuing-life-support-inhumane-liverpool-court-hears|title=Alfie Evans: continuing life support 'inhumane', Liverpool court hears|first=Josh|last=Halliday|date=1 February 2018|website=the Guardian}} In September 2017, Italian doctors from Bambino Gesù Hospital produced an assessment report on the possibility of transferring Alfie to Italy. According to their report on the case, they could offer prolonged ventilator support, with a surgical [[Tracheotomy|tracheostomy]] and would remove a [[Nasogastric intubation|nasogastric tube]], replacing it with a [[gastrostomy]]. During assessment, Alfie suffered "epileptic seizures induced by [[Proprioception|proprioceptive stimuli]]", the report warned "due to stimulations related to the transportation and flight, those seizures might induce further damage to the brain, [putting] the whole procedure of transportation at risk." Alfie remained in Alder Hey Hospital for the duration of 2017, with no improvement in his condition. At the end of the year, the hospital applied to have [[life support]] switched off. == Publicity and public reaction == Alfie Evans' case drew significant public attention in the United Kingdom and overseas, with his parents establishing "Alfie's Army", an online campaign group dedicated to seeking further treatment and opposing the withdrawal of life support.{{Cite web|url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/alfie-evans-timeline-legal-battle-14312017|title=Alfie Evans timeline: How one young boy captured the hearts of millions|last=|first=|date=|website=Liverpool Echo|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=30 April 2018}} Supporters established a petition on [[change.org]], calling on [[Alder Hey Children's Hospital|Alder Hey Hospital]] to allow Alfie Evans to be transferred to a hospital of his parents' choice. His parents also approached Dr Michio Hirano, a US-based neurologist who had offered treatment in the [[Charlie Gard case|case of Charlie Gard]]. Alfie's parents claimed a parental right to make decisions about their son's care, arguing that the hospital itself should not be able to make care-decisions for their son without their consent.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-43893709|title=Alfie Evans: When are parents denied the final say?|last=|first=|date=|website=BBC News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=30 April 2018}} Large protests emerged outside Alder Hey Hospital on 12 April after his family insisted on their right to take him home.{{Cite web|url=https://news.sky.com/story/alfie-evans-police-called-to-alder-hey-childrens-hospital-as-hundreds-join-protest-11328278|title=Alfie Evans: Police called to Alder Hey Children's Hospital as hundreds join protest|date=13 April 2018|website=Sky News|access-date=26 April 2018}} On 16 April, [[Merseyside Police]] launched an investigation into "instances of verbal abuse and acts of intimidation" with judges raising concerns about threatening conduct by protests towards hospital staff. Alfie's parents apologised, saying they did not intend to "harm or cause conflict or upset".{{cite web|url=https://www.merseyside.police.uk/news/latest-news/2018/04/merseyside-police-comment-on-ongoing-issues-at-alder-hey-hospital/|title=Merseyside Police comment on ongoing issues at Alder Hey hospital|date=16 April 2018|website=www.merseyside.police.uk|language=en|access-date=26 April 2018}} Merseyside Police Chief Inspector Chris Gibson released a statement regarding social media posts regarding the Alder Hey Hospital and Alfie Evans situation: "[[Malicious Communications Act 1988|malicious communications]] and threatening behaviour will be investigated and, where necessary, will be acted upon."{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/merseypolice/posts/1774908912565745|title=Merseyside Police|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=26 April 2018}} === Overseas support === On 18 April 2018 Alfie's father flew to Rome for a 20-minute meeting with [[Pope Francis]].{{cite web|url=https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2018-04/pope-francis-meeting-with-father-alfie-evans.html|title=The Pope's meeting with the father of Alfie Evans — Vatican News|date=18 April 2018|publisher=|access-date=28 April 2018}} The case was commented on by the Pope via [[Twitter]], who stated his "sincere hope that everything necessary may be done in order to continue compassionately accompanying little Alfie Evans, and that the deep suffering of his parents may be heard."{{cite tweet|number=981606519702786048|user=Pontifex|title=It is my sincere hope that everything necessary may be done in order to continue compassionately accompanying little Alfie Evans, and that the deep suffering of his parents may be heard. I am praying for Alfie, for his family and for all who are involved.|date=4 April 2018}}{{cite tweet|number=988496588283826177|user=Pontifex|title=Moved by the prayers and immense solidarity shown little Alfie Evans, I renew my appeal that the suffering of his parents may be heard and that their desire to seek new forms of treatment may be granted.|date=23 April 2018}} He restated his support after the removal of life support, saying "Moved by the prayers and immense solidarity shown little Alfie Evans, I renew my appeal that the suffering of his parents may be heard and that their desire to seek new forms of treatment may be granted."{{cite web|url=https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2018-04/pope-alfie-evans-twitter-appeal.html|title=Pope Francis renews appeal for Alfie Evans — Vatican News|date=25 April 2018|publisher=}} The President of Poland [[Andrzej Duda]] also expressed his support.{{cite tweet|number=989054152155258880|user=AndrzejDuda|title=Alfie Evans must be saved! His brave little body has proved again that the miracle of life can be stronger than death. Perhaps all that's needed is some good will on the part of decision makers. Alfie, we pray for you and your recovery!|date=24 April 2018}} On 23 April, Alfie was granted Italian citizenship under the request of [[Brothers of Italy]]'s leader [[Giorgia Meloni]]. The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Italy)|Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] said it hoped Alfie would be allowed "immediate transfer to Italy".{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-merseyside-43872678|title=Alfie Evans granted Italian citizenship|date=23 April 2018|website=BBC News|access-date=23 April 2018}} == Legal proceedings == {{Infobox court case |name = Alder Hey NHS Trust -v- Evans |court = [[High Court of Justice#Family Division|High Court of Justice (Family Division)]] |image = |imagesize = |imagelink = |imagealt = |caption = |full name = |date decided = {{start date|df=yes|2018|02|20}} (High Court), {{start date|df=yes|2018|03|06}} (Court of Appeal) |citations = |ECLI = |transcripts = |judges = |number of judges = |decision by = |concurring = |dissenting = |concur/dissent = |prior actions = |appealed from = |appealed to = |subsequent actions = |related actions = |opinions = |keywords = |italic title = no }} On 19 December 2017, Alder Hey applied to the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] to withdraw parental rights from Alfie's parents and to withdraw ventilation.{{cite web|url=https://news.sky.com/story/timeline-the-fight-to-keep-alfie-evans-alive-11344694|title=Timeline: The fight to keep Alfie Evans alive |publisher=}} The case was heard at a public hearing in the [[High Court of Justice#Family Division|Family Division of the High Court]] in London. Alder Hey claimed that continuing life-support treatment would not be in the best interests of Alfie and sought declaration that "is not lawful that such treatment continue". Lawyers acting on the hospital's behalf further claimed that further treatment for Alfie would be "unkind and inhumane". A doctor treating Alfie further stated that there was "no hope" for the child, and that he was in a [[Persistent vegetative state|semi-vegetative state]] from a degenerative neurological condition that medics have not been able to definitively identify. The parents denied this, with Alfie's father claiming that his son "looks him in the eye" and "wants help".{{cite web|url=https://www.judiciary.gov.uk/judgments/alder-hey-nhs-trust-v-evans|title=Alder Hey NHS Trust -v- Evans [2018] EWHC 308 (Fam)|date=20 February 2018|access-date=23 April 2018}} The High Court ruled in favour of the hospital on 20 February 2018. In their judgement, the High Court stated that an MRI scan taken in February 2018 revealed that "[Alfie's] brain [was] entirely beyond recovery" and that "the brain was now only able to generate seizure" with "progressive destruction of the [[white matter]] of the brain which Dr R interpreted as now appearing almost identical to water and [[cerebrospinal fluid]] (CSF)." The Court noted that the medical consensus, including of doctors asked to testify by the parents, was that Alfie had a fatal and untreatable condition, but they differed over the best course of action concerning his end-of-life care. High Court judge [[High Court judge (England and Wales)|Mr Justice]] [[Anthony Hayden]] concluded that "I am satisfied that continued ventilatory support is no longer in Alfie's best interest". ===Appeals=== Alfie's parents appealed against the decision in late February. On 6 March, the [[Court of Appeal (England and Wales)|Court of Appeal]] upheld the earlier ruling of the High Court.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWCA/Civ/2018/550.html|title=E (A Child), Re [2018] EWCA Civ 550|last=|first=|date=6 March 2018|website=[[British and Irish Legal Information Institute]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} They stated that the High Court judge was "meticulous and thorough", and that medical evidence showed Alfie was "deeply comatose" and "to all intents and purposes unaware of his surroundings". The parents applied to the [[Supreme Court of the United Kingdom]] on 20 March, which refused the right for another appeal.{{cite web|title=Permission to appeal determination in the matter of Alfie Evans — The Supreme Court|url=https://www.supremecourt.uk/news/permission-to-appeal-determination-in-the-matter-of-alfie-evans.html|website=[[Supreme Court of the United Kingdom]]|access-date=26 April 2018|language=en|date=20 March 2018}} On 28 March the [[European Court of Human Rights]] ruled the case inadmissible, finding no violation of human rights.{{cite web|url=https://hudoc.echr.coe.int/app/conversion/pdf/?library=ECHR&id=003-6046074-7771568&filename=Decision%20Evans%20v.%20United%20Kingdom%20-%20complaint%20declared%20inadmissible.pdf|title=ECHR declares application by parents of Alfie Evans inadmissible|date=28 March 2018|access-date=23 April 2018|format=pdf}} In a High Court judgement of 11 April 2018, the judge remarked that "by the end of February the connective pathways within the white matter of the brain which facilitate rudimentary sensation — hearing, touch, taste and sight, had been obliterated. They were no longer even identifiable on the MRI scan".{{cite web|title=Alder Hey Children's NHS Foundation Trust v Evans & Ors [2018] EWHC 818 (Fam)|url=http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Fam/2018/818.html|website=[[British and Irish Legal Information Institute]]|access-date=26 April 2018|date=11 April 2018}} The High Court backed an end-of-life care plan drawn up by medical specialists attached to Alfie Evans' case. Alfie's father said that Alfie was wrongly "detained" at Alder Hey. High Court judge Hayden dismissed that complaint, and appeal judges upheld his decision.{{cite web|last1=Pidd|first1=Helen|title=Alfie Evans' parents lose latest legal battle at UK's highest court|url=https://www.theguardian.com/law/2018/apr/20/alfie-evans-parents-lose-latest-legal-battle-uk-highest-supreme-court|website=the Guardian|access-date=23 April 2018|language=en|date=20 April 2018}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWCA/Civ/2018/805.html|title=Evans & Anor v Alder Hey Children's NHS Foundation Trust & Ors [2018] EWCA Civ 805|last=|first=|date=16 April 2018|website=[[British and Irish Legal Information Institute]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} On 17 April Mr Evans and Ms James asked the Supreme Court to consider their case again. Their application to appeal was refused on 20 April. The justices wrote, "Alfie looks like a normal baby, but the unanimous opinion of the doctors who have examined him and the scans of his brain is that almost all of his brain has been destroyed. No-one knows why. But that it has happened and is continuing to happen cannot be denied. [...] there is no hope of his ever getting better."{{cite web|title=Permission to appeal application in the matter of Alfie Evans — The Supreme Court|url=https://www.supremecourt.uk/news/permission-to-appeal-application-in-the-matter-of-alfie-evans.html|website=[[Supreme Court of the United Kingdom]]|access-date=26 April 2018|language=en|date=20 April 2018}} The European Court of Human Rights again determined their appeal on these grounds to be inadmissable.{{cite web|title=European court rejects plea from parents of Alfie Evans|url=http://www.itv.com/news/2018-04-23/european-court-rejects-plea-from-parents-of-alfie-evans|website=ITV News|access-date=23 April 2018}} The case concerned the family's argument that the prevention of Alfie's transfer from Alder Hey Hospital constituted deprivation of liberty and a violation of Article 5 (right to liberty and security) of the European Convention on Human Rights.{{cite web|title=ECHR finds fresh application from family of Alfie Evans inadmissible|url=https://www.echr.coe.int/Documents/Decision_Evans_v_UK.pdf|publisher=European Court of Human Rights|access-date=26 April 2018|format=pdf|date=23 April 2018}} The decision resulted in a [[protest]] of at least 200 people taking place outside of Alder Hey hospital.{{cite web|title=Alfie protesters try to storm hospital|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-merseyside-43867132|website=BBC News|access-date=23 April 2018|date=23 April 2018}} ===Withdrawal of life support=== On 23 April, it was reported that Alfie's life support had been withdrawn.{{cite web|last1=Pidd|first1=Helen|last2=Rawlinson|first2=Kevin|last3=Perraudin|first3=Frances|title=Life support has been withdrawn from Alfie Evans, says father|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/apr/23/alfie-evans-european-court-human-rights-life-support|website=the Guardian|access-date=24 April 2018|date=23 April 2018}} Alfie continued to breathe after the removal of his breathing tube, although his parents gave conflicting reports, at one time claiming they needed to perform [[Mouth-to-mouth resuscitation|mouth-to-mouth resuscitation]].{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/alfie-evans-latest-parents-giving-severely-ill-toddler-mouth-tomouth-resuscitation-to-keep-him-alive-a3822741.html|title=Alfie Evans' parents 'giving toddler mouth-to-mouth' to keep him alive|publisher=[[London Evening Standard]]|date=25 April 2018|access-date=28 April 2018}} Other than a post on social media no evidence of mouth-to-mouth ever being performed has ever been made public. Alfie's father stated to the media the next morning that Alfie had been breathing unassisted since shortly after life-support had been withdrawn, and that life-support should be reinstated.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/04/24/alfie-evans-father-reveals-son-has-breathing-unassisted-life/ Alfie Evans' father reveals son has been breathing unassisted after life support stops], The Telegraph, 24 April 2018. The evening of the same day, High Court judge Justice Hayden rejected the parents' appeal for permission to fly their son to a hospital in Italy. The judge concluded how previously he had come, "the consensus of every doctor from every country who had ever evaluated Alfie's condition, to the inevitable conclusion (following 7 days of evidence) that Alfie's brain had been so corroded by his Neurodegenerative Brain Disorder that there was simply no prospect of recovery. By the time I requested the updated MRI scan in February, the signal intensity was so bright that it revealed a brain that had been almost entirely wiped out. In simple terms the brain consisted only of water and CSF. [...] All that could be offered by the Bambino Gesu Hospital in Rome was an alternative palliative care plan."{{cite web|title=Alder Hey Children's NHS Foundation Trust v Evans & Anor [2018] EWHC 953 (Fam)|url=http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Fam/2018/953.html|website=[[British and Irish Legal Information Institute]]|access-date=26 April 2018|date=24 April 2018}} According to the ''[[Liverpool Echo]]'', Alfie's father told reporters later that evening that the court had said it could set aside three judges that evening to hear his case again.[https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/alfie-evans-latest-parents-say-14572790 Alfie Evans latest: Parents say they had to keep him alive using mouth to mouth resuscitation], Liverpool Echo, 24 April 2018. On 25 April, the appeal was rejected.{{cite web|title=Alfie Evans: Appeal court hearing 'extraordinary and tragic'|url=https://news.sky.com/story/alfie-evans-appeal-court-hearing-extraordinary-and-tragic-11346723|website=Sky News|access-date=26 April 2018|date=25 April 2018}} Alfie Evans' father sought to issue a private prosecution alleging murder against several staff members at Alder Hey.{{cite web|last1=Sawer|first1=Patrick|title=Alfie Evans's father threatened private murder prosecution against doctors treating the toddler |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/04/25/alfie-evanss-father-threatened-private-murder-prosecution-against/|website=The Telegraph|access-date=26 April 2018|date=25 April 2018}}{{bettersource|date=May 2018}} A statement had been prepared by Pavel Stroilov of the [[Christian Legal Centre]], but was rejected by a district judge. On 26 April, Mr Evans issued a statement, thanking supporters, and staff at Alder Hey Hospital. He stated the family wished to "form a relationship, build a bridge and walk across it" with the hospital where their son has been treated and work with the treating team on a "plan that provides our boy with the dignity and comfort that he needs".{{cite web|title=Alfie Evans' family pledge to 'build bridge' with doctors|url=https://news.sky.com/story/alfie-evans-family-to-build-bridge-with-doctors-11347612|website=Sky News|access-date=26 April 2018|date=26 April 2018}} ==Outcome== Alfie died at 2:30 a.m. on 28 April 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://news.sky.com/story/alfie-evans-dies-after-parents-lose-legal-fight-for-life-support-11344883|title=Alfie Evans dies after parents lose legal fight for life support|work=Sky News|access-date=28 April 2018|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/04/28/alfie-evans-dies-long-running-legal-battle/|title=Alfie Evans dies after long-running legal battle|last=Graham|first=Chris|date=28 April 2018|work=The Daily Telegraph|access-date=28 April 2018|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}} Later that day his father, Tom Evans, released a statement on Facebook announcing his death: "My gladiator lay down his shield and gained his wings... absolutely heartbroken."{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-43933056|title=Legal battle toddler Alfie Evans dies|date=28 April 2018|work=BBC News|access-date=28 April 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Medical ethics cases|state=collapsed}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Evans, Alfie}} [[Category:2018 controversies]] [[Category:2017 in British law]] [[Category:2018 in British law]] [[Category:Medical controversies in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Medical lawsuits]]

{{about|the public event in Las Vegas|the political party formerly called America's Independent Party|America's Party (political party)}} {{coord|36|7|15|N|115|10|20|W|region:US-NV_type:landmark|display=title}}
'''America's Party''' is the free [[New Year's Eve]] event held on the [[Las Vegas Strip]] put together by [[Las Vegas Events]] and the [[Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority]].<ref name=lvcva>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegas2005.org/mediacenter/releases/nye-1130.html|title=VEGAS SIZZLES WITH PARTY OF THE CENTURY|author=|date=|work=|publisher=|accessdate=2009-12-16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101227143232/http://www.lasvegas2005.org/mediacenter/releases/nye-1130.html|archive-date=2010-12-27|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The party is telecast with special events for the Eastern Time Zone as ''[[America's Party: Live from Las Vegas]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegasevents.com/signature-event-info.php?id=5 |title=America's Party 2010 |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Las Vegas Events |accessdate=2009-12-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110610205314/http://www.lasvegasevents.com/signature-event-info.php?id=5 |archivedate=June 10, 2011 }}</ref> The party also encompasses the paid event held in the [[Fremont Street Experience]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://events.frommers.com/sisp/index.htm?fx=event&event_id=158156|title=America's Party|author=|date=|work=|publisher=|accessdate=2009-12-16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711045135/http://events.frommers.com/sisp/index.htm?fx=event&event_id=158156|archive-date=2011-07-11|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
The party's high point is generally the [[firework]]s show at midnight by [[Fireworks by Grucci]].<ref name=lvcva/>
== History == America's Party 2002, titled ''A Star-Spangled New Year'', had [[Ryan Seacrest]] hosting the event on the TV broadcast America's Party: Live from Las Vegas.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0352164/ |title=America's Party: Live from Las Vegas (2002) (TV) |author= |date= |work= |publisher= |accessdate=2009-12-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://newsletter.casinocity.com/Issue69/ |title=Las Vegas Hosted "America's Party:Las Vegas New Year 2002" |author= |date= |work= |publisher= |accessdate=2009-12-16}}</ref>
For the 2003 party, Ryan Seacrest hosted the event on the TV broadcast America's Party: Live from Las Vegas.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0397034/ |title=America's Party: Live from Las Vegas (2003) (TV) |author= |date= |work= |publisher= |accessdate=2009-12-16}}</ref> [[Pyro Spectacular]] provided the fireworks for this show.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/americas-party-returns-as-las-vegas-ushers-in-new-year-76890902.html |title=America's Party Returns As Las Vegas Ushers in New Year |author= |date= |work= |publisher=PR Newswire |accessdate=2013-08-13}}</ref>
America's party 2005 celebrated the 100th anniversary of Las Vegas and began with a [[B-1 Lancer|B-1]] bomber flyover of the Strip. Fireworks were launched from the [[Excalibur Hotel and Casino|Excalibur]], [[MGM Grand Las Vegas|MGM Grand]], [[Monte Carlo Resort and Casino|Monte Carlo]], [[Bally's Las Vegas|Bally's]], [[Flamingo Las Vegas|Flamingo]], [[The Venetian, Las Vegas|Venetian]], [[Treasure Island]], [[Stardust Resort & Casino|Stardust]], [[Circus Circus Las Vegas|Circus-Circus]] and [[Stratosphere Las Vegas|Stratosphere]].<ref name=lvcva/>
America's Party 2007 was launched from 10 rooftops with coverage from [[CD USA]] and [[DirecTV]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.travelworldguides.com/travel-forums/north-american-travel-forum/64710-las-vegas-celebrates-new-year-americas-party.html |title=LAS VEGAS CELEBRATES NEW YEAR WITH AMERICA'S PARTY |author= |date= |work= |publisher= |accessdate=2009-12-16}}</ref>
America's Party 2008. ''The Best is Yet to Come'', was launched from the MGM Grand, Planet Hollywood, Flamingo Las Vegas, Venetian, Treasure Island (TI), Circus-Circus and Stratosphere.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lasvegasfocus.com/news/2007/12/las-vegas-new-years-eve-celebration-americas-party/ |title= Las Vegas New Years Eve Celebration: "America’s Party"|author= |date=2007-12-19 |work= |publisher= |accessdate=2009-12-16}}</ref>
For America's Party 2009, the traditional rooftop fireworks display was replaced by a ground-based show due to additional fire department requirements that were put in place following the [[Monte Carlo Hotel fire]]. The firework for the ''Takin' it to the Streets'' show, were launched from: [[Mandalay Bay Convention Center]], [[Luxor Hotel]], MGM Grand, [[Caesars Palace]], Treasure Island, [[Las Vegas Convention Center]] and the Stratosphere Casino.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.finehomeslv.com/blog/americas-party-las-vegas-new-year-2009-is-takin-it-to-the-streets/ |title= Americas Party Las Vegas New Year 2009 Is "Takin; It To The Streets"|author= |date= |work= |publisher= |accessdate=2009-12-16}}</ref>
The fireworks return to the rooftops for the 2010 party, ''A Vegas Celebration", using the MGM Grand, [[Aria Resort & Casino|Aria]], [[Planet Hollywood Resort and Casino|Planet Hollywood Resort]], Caesar's Palace, Venetian Resort, Treasure Island and the Stratosphere Tower.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegasevents.com/pdf/sigevents-2010-amparty-firinglocations.pdf |title=untitled |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Las Vegas Events |accessdate=2009-12-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110610210154/http://www.lasvegasevents.com/pdf/sigevents-2010-amparty-firinglocations.pdf |archivedate=June 10, 2011 }}</ref>
The 2011 version launches an 8-minute 6 second show by Fireworks by Grucci from MGM Grand, Aria, Planet Hollywood, Caesar's Palace, The Venetian, Treasure Island and the Stratosphere Tower.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://prvegas.com/2010/12/america%E2%80%99s-party-las-vegas-new-year-2011/ |title=America’s Party: Las Vegas New Year 2011 |author= |date= |work= |publisher=PRVegas News and Information Blog |accessdate=December 30, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715125053/http://prvegas.com/2010/12/america%E2%80%99s-party-las-vegas-new-year-2011/ |archivedate=July 15, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=America’s Party Fireworks to remain on rooftops |author= |url=http://www.ktnv.com/story/13286897/americas-party-fireworks-display-to-remain-on-the-rooftops?redirected=true |newspaper=[[KTNV]] |date=December 31, 2010 |accessdate=December 31, 2010}}{{dead link|date=April 2013}}</ref> Grucci also provides a separate fireworks show for the Fremont street experience.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.grucci.com/indexbravo.html?page=51 |title=National Events Schedule |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Fireworks by Grucci |accessdate=December 30, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101217114336/http://grucci.com/indexbravo.html?page=51| archivedate= 17 December 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
For 2012 the show was launched from the [[Tropicana Resort & Casino|Tropicana]], MGM Grand, Aria, Planet Hollywood, Caesars Palace, Treasure Island, The Venetian and the Stratosphere.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vegas.com/newyears/ |title=Celebrate New Year's Eve in Vegas in 2011 - 2012! |author= |date= |work= |publisher= |accessdate=December 14, 2011}}</ref> The show is being produced by Fireworks by Grucci.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://grucci.com/indexbravo.html?page=51|title=National Events Schedule|author=|date=|work=|publisher=Fireworks by Grucci|accessdate=December 14, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101217114336/http://grucci.com/indexbravo.html?page=51|archive-date=2010-12-17|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
== Notes == {{reflist|colwidth=35em}}

{{Unreferenced|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox film |image=Black_August_DVD.jpg |caption=Black August DVD Cover |director=Samm Styles |producer=Tcinque Sampson |starring=[[Gary Dourdan]]
Darren Bridgett
Ezra Stanley
'Big' Leroy Mobley
Don Williams |cinematography=Kev Robertson |editing=Judd Flemming |music=Juan 'Uglyfingers' Blair |country={{flagicon|USA}} United States |language=English |released=2007 |runtime=116 min. }} '''Black August''' is a 2007 drama film produced by [[Tcinque Sampson]] and directed by [[Samm Styles]]. The film centers on the story of [[George Jackson (Black Panther)|George Jackson]]'s life. ==Plot== The movie covers the last 14 months of [[George Jackson (Black Panther)|George Jackson]]'s life as well as the conditions in California's prison industrial complex. George Jackson would spend 11 years incarcerated (7 of which were in solitary confinement) for a $70 gas station robbery crime in 1960. He was 18 years of age when the sentence of one year-to-life was handed down to him. ''Black August'' encompasses the infamous [[Soledad Brothers]] case in which George Jackson, Fleeta Drumgo, and John Clucheette are accused of murdering a Soledad prison guard, in retaliation for the killing of three Black inmates involved in a fight with White inmates on an exercise yard in Soledad State Prison, [[Soledad, California]]. The film reflects on the general prison movement in the late 1960s and early 1970s, and the role the [[Black Panther Party]] would play in organizing both the outside communities as well as the Party's influence on prisoners across the country. As a prison organizer, George was recruited by Black Panther Party founder [[Huey P. Newton]] to head the Peoples Army, a euphemism which would become synonymous with the name [[Black Guerrilla Family]]. The film points out the conspiratorial nature of occurrences, which surrounded the events of August 7, 1970, where Jackson's 17-year-old younger brother, Jonathan Jackson, played by Ezra J. Stanley, would be killed at the [[Marin County]] Courthouse, at [[San Rafael, California]], during a hostage takeover attempt to leverage against the release of the elder Jackson, and the other [[Soledad Brothers]]. The younger Jackson and three others would be killed, including Superior Judge [[Harold Haley]] and August 21, 1971, where George Jackson himself, and five others would be killed at [[San Quentin State Prison]], California, during what is described as a prison break attempt. After a nationwide manhunt, [[Angela Davis]] would be captured and stand trial in connection with the [[Marin County]] Court House liberation attempt by Jonathan Jackson, accused of conspiracy in supplying 17-year-old Jonathan Jackson with the weapons used. George Jackson is accused of smuggling a 9mm pistol and extra clips concealed under an Afro-wig, into the prison cellblock following a visit by Attorney [[Stephen Bingham]]. Stephen Bingham would leave the country, not returning to face charges until 14 years later. Both, Davis and Bingham would be acquitted. Others possibly involved in connection with the events of August 21, 1971 would never be questioned. ==Cast== *[[Gary Dourdan]] as George Jackson *Darren Bridgett as David Dryer *Ezra Stanley as Jonathan Jackson *'Big' Leroy Mobley as Lumumba *Don Williams as FBI Agent Walker ==DVD information== Full Screen, Original Aspect Ratio - 1.85
Runtime: 116 mins
Dolby Surround 5.1 - English
Subtitles: Subtitles
Original Product Release Date: 02/12/2008 ==External links== *[http://www.blackaugustdvd.com Official Website] *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0383929/ IMDB.com] *[http://whv.warnerbros.com/WHVPORTAL/Portal/product.jsp?OID=30911&S=website Warner Home Video] *[http://criticalwomen.blogspot.com/2008/01/black-august-on-dvd-soledad-brother.html Review: Critical Women On Film (Prairie Miller)] {{DEFAULTSORT:Black August (Film)}} [[Category:African-American films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films set in San Quentin State Prison]]

{{italic title}} [[File:Uncommon law - negatiable cow.jpg|thumb|upright|The case of the ''negotiable cow,'' collected in ''[[Uncommon Law]]'']] '''''Board of Inland Revenue v Haddock''''' (also known as '''the negotiable cow''') is a fictitious legal case written by the humorist [[A. P. Herbert]] for [[Punch (magazine)|''Punch'' magazine]] as part of his series of ''Misleading Cases in the Common Law''. It was first published in book form in ''More Misleading Cases in the Common Law'' (Methuen, 1930).<ref>[http://ansible.co.uk/misc/apherbert.html A.P. Herbert's Misleading Cases]</ref> The case evolved into an [[urban legend]].
==Summary of the case==
The case<ref name="uncommonlaw">{{cite |title=Uncommon Law |authorlink=A. P. Herbert |publisher=[[Methuen Publishing|Methuen]] |place=Great Britain |date=1935 |last=Herbert|first=Alan P. }}</ref> involved a Mr Albert Haddock, often an ingenious litigant in Herbert's writing. In this case, Haddock had been in disagreement with the Collector of Taxes over the size of his tax bill. Haddock complained that the sum was excessive, particularly in view of the inadequate [[Consideration under English law|consideration]] he believed that he received from that Government in service. Eventually the Collector demanded £57 and 10 shillings.
Haddock appeared at the offices of the Collector of Taxes and delivered a white cow "of malevolent aspect". On the cow was stencilled in red ink:
:''To the London and Literary Bank, Limited'' :''Pay the Collector of Taxes, who is no gentleman, or Order, the sum of fifty seven pounds £57/0/0 (and may he rot!) '' :''ALBERT HADDOCK''
Haddock tendered the cow in payment of his bill and demanded a receipt.
During the hearing, the fictitious judge, Sir Basil String, enquired whether [[stamp duty]] had been paid. The prosecutor, Sir Joshua Hoot [[Queen's Counsel|KC]] confirmed that a two-penny stamp was affixed to the dexter horn of the cow. The collector declined the cow, objecting that it would be impossible to pay it into a bank account. Haddock suggested that he [[Negotiable instrument|endorse]] the cow to a third party to whom he might owe money, adding that "there must be many persons in that position".
Sir Joshua informed the court that the collector did try to endorse the cheque on its back, in this case on the abdomen. However, Sir Joshua explained: "[t]he cow ... appeared to resent endorsement and adopted a menacing posture."
The collector abandoned the attempt and declined to take the cheque. Haddock led the cow away and was arrested in [[Trafalgar Square]] for causing an obstruction, leading to the co-joined criminal case, '''''R. v Haddock'''''.
He testified that he had tendered a cheque in payment of income tax. A cheque was only an order to a bank to pay money to the person in possession of the cheque or a person named on the cheque, and there was nothing in law to say it must be on paper of specified dimensions. A cheque, he argued, could be written on notepaper. He said he had "drawn cheques on the backs of menus, on napkins, on handkerchiefs, on the labels of wine bottles; all these cheques had been duly honoured by his bank and passed through the Bankers’ Clearing House". He thought that there was no distinction in law between a cheque on a napkin and a cheque on a cow.
When asked as to motive, he said he had not a piece of paper to hand. Horses and other animals used to be seen frequently in the streets of London. He admitted on [[cross-examination]] that he may have had in his mind an idea to ridicule the taxman. "But why not? There is no law against ridiculing the income tax."<ref name="uncommonlaw"/>
In relation to the criminal prosecution, Haddock said it was a nice thing if in the heart of the commercial capital of the world a man could not convey a negotiable instrument down the street without being arrested. If a disturbance was caused by a crowd, the policeman should arrest the crowd, not him.
The judge, sympathetic to Haddock, found in his favour on the tax claim and prosecution for causing a disturbance. By tendering and being refused the cow, the other parties were [[estoppel|estopped]] from then demanding it later.
==Television adaptation== ''Board of Inland Revenue v. Haddock'' was dramatised for BBC television as "The Negotiable Cow" as the opening of the first series of ''A. P. Herbert's Misleading Cases'' in 1967, with [[Roy Dotrice]] as Albert Haddock and [[Alastair Sim]] as Mr Justice Swallow.
==Citations== Although the case is fictitious, it has been referred to in judicial decisions.
In ''Messing v Bank of America'' (2002) at paragraph 1<ref>[http://www.courts.state.md.us/opinions/coa/2003/27a02.pdf 373 Md. 672; 821 A.2d. 22]</ref> the [[Maryland Court of Appeals]] observed: "The circumstances which gave rise to the case before us are, in terms of its genesis, reminiscent of those described in the case of ''Board of Inland Revenue v. Haddock''."
In the English case of {{cite bailii|litigants=Victor Chandeler International Ltd v The Commissioners of Custom and Excise and Teletext Limited|year=1999|court=EWHC|division=Ch |num=214}} [[Gavin Lightman (judge)|Mr Justice Lightman]] stated that a document, in the context of the [[Betting and Gaming Duties Act 1981]], "must be inanimate: neither a person nor A.P. Herbert's 'negotiable cow' can constitute a document."<ref>At paragraph 11.</ref>
Herbert reported that the now defunct ''Memphis Press-Scimitar'' (formerly published by the [[E. W. Scripps Company]]) published an article on the case in 1967, assuming it to have been factual.<ref>See report in Snopes Urban legends [http://www.snopes.com/business/bank/cowcheck.asp] and the definition of "chose in action" in this [http://sixthformlaw.info/03_dictionary/dict_c.htm legal dictionary].</ref>
==Comparable real life cases== Negotiable instruments and other legal documents have been written on unusual surfaces. Documented cases provide illustrations of [[will (law)|wills]] on the side of empty egg-shells,<ref>See ''Hodson v Barnes'' (1926) 43 TLR 71. The will was rejected from probate.</ref> and [[cheque]]s being written on a variety of strange surfaces.<ref>A commonly cited example is tax protests in the United Kingdom in the 1970s when taxpayers would print their cheques on rigid boards measuring approximately 3 feet by 1½ feet.[https://www.theguardian.com/notesandqueries/query/0,5753,-20434,00.html]</ref>
An often-cited example is a Canadian farmer who, while trapped under his own tractor, carved a [[holographic will]] into the tractor's fender. The fender was probated and stood as his will, and is currently on display at the [[law library]] of the [[University of Saskatchewan College of Law]].<ref>On Campus News, January 23, 2009: [http://news.usask.ca/archived_ocn/09-jan-23/see_what_we_found.php The Last Will and Testament of Cecil George Harris]</ref>
In [[Halakha|Jewish law]] a [[get (divorce document)|get]] can be written on any durable material, including the horn of a cow. If the horn is still attached to the cow, the husband must give the wife the whole cow.<ref>[[Mishnah]] [[Nashim#Gittin ("Bills of Divorce")|Gittin 2.3]]),[http://kodesh.snunit.k12.il/b/h/h36.htm]</ref>
==Similar fictional cases==
Another A. P. Herbert "misleading case" concerns "The egg of exchange". The question there was whether a cheque written on an egg could be paid into a bank, given the risk of the egg breaking or going bad. It was suggested that the cheque could be boiled.
Yet another "misleading case", also ''Inland Revenue v Haddock'', was cited in a debate in the [[House of Lords]] on 14 July 2004.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200304/ldhansrd/vo040714/text/40714-23.htm |title=House of Lords Hansard |publisher=[[Office of Public Sector Information|Stationery Office]] |date=14 July 2004 |location=(pt 23) |accessdate=26 August 2010 }}</ref> In this, Mr. Haddock successfully argued that, during a period when judges had their salaries reduced by 30% because of financial emergency, they could not hear cases relating to the Inland Revenue because they had a [[conflict of interest|personal interest]] in the outcome.
==Footnotes== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080716090033/http://www.hk-lawyer.com/2002-10/Oct02-staredecisis.htm Excerpt of the article from the ''Hong Kong lawyer''] *[http://www.snopes.com/business/bank/cowcheck.asp Urban legends reference page] *[http://www.texasbar.com/saywhat/weblog/buchmeyer_article_archive/mar86.asp Excerpt from the Texas bar website]

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox criminal | name = Bruce Reynolds | image = Bruce Reynolds.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Bruce Richard Reynolds | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=y|1931|09|07}} | birth_place = [[Charing Cross Hospital]], [[Strand, London|Strand]], [[London]], [[England]] | residence = | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=y|2013|02|28|1931|09|07}} | death_place = [[Croydon]], Greater London, England | cause = | resting_place = | nationality = | alias = Keith Clement Miller
Keith Hillier | allegiance = | motive = Financial gain/enjoyment | charge = | conviction = '''1957:''' Assault and robbery, 3½ years [[HMP Wandsworth]]
'''1969:''' [[Great Train Robbery (1963)|Great Train Robbery]], 25 years [[HMP Durham]]
'''1980:''' Drug dealing, 3 years [[HMP Maidstone]] | conviction_penalty = | conviction_status = | occupation = Messenger, Cyclist, Antiques dealer | spouse = Frances (until her death) | parents = | children = [[Nick Reynolds (sculptor)|Nick Reynolds]] }} '''Bruce Richard Reynolds''' (7 September 1931 – 28 February 2013) was an [[English people|English]] [[criminal]] who masterminded the 1963 [[Great Train Robbery (1963)|Great Train Robbery]].{{cite news |title=Bruce Reynolds |date=1 March 2013 |work=The Daily Telegraph |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |page=33}} At the time it was Britain's largest robbery, netting {{currency|2,631,684|GBP}}, equivalent to £{{Inflation|UK|2.6|1963}} million today.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-23256395|title=Great Train Robbery: How Bruce Reynolds became a writer|accessdate=12 July 2013|date=12 July 2013|author=Jake Arnott|publisher=BBC News}} Reynolds spent five years on the run before being sentenced to 25 years in 1969. He was released in 1978. He wrote three books and performed with the band [[Alabama 3]], for whom his son, Nick, plays.{{cite news|first=Bruce |last=Reynolds |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/jan/29/ukcrime.comment |title=Comment: Anyone can steal - but few get away |publisher=The Guardian |date=29 January 2008 |accessdate=23 December 2013}} ==Early life== Bruce Richard Reynolds was born at [[Charing Cross Hospital]], in the [[Strand, London|Strand]], central London, the only child of Thomas Richard and Dorothy Margaret (née Keen). He was initially brought up in [[Putney]], and his mother, a [[nurse]], died in 1935 when he was aged four. His father, a trade-union activist at the [[Ford Dagenham assembly plant]], married again, and the family moved to [[Gants Hill]]. Reynolds found it difficult to live with his father and stepmother, choosing often to stay with one or other of his grandmothers. During the [[London Blitz]] of the [[World War II|Second World War]] he was evacuated to [[Suffolk]] and then to [[Warwickshire]].{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} On leaving school at 14½, Reynolds failed the eyesight test to join the [[Royal Navy]], and decided he wanted to become a [[foreign correspondent]], so he applied in person for a job at [[Northcliffe House]]. Employed first as a messenger boy, he then worked in the accounts department of the ''[[Daily Mail]]''.{{cite news |publisher=The Guardian |date=1 April 1995 |title=Interview: One of your very uncommon criminals}} By the age of 17 he had become bored with the routine and was working in the Bland/Sutton Institute of Pathology at [[Middlesex Hospital]], before joining [[Claud Butler]] as a [[bicycle messenger]] and a member of their semi-professional racing team, where he first met criminals and began a life of crime.{{cite web|url=http://idler.co.uk/conversations-bruce-reynolds/ |title=In conversation with... Bruce Reynolds |publisher=Idler magazine |date=14 March 1996 |accessdate=28 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420212102/http://idler.co.uk/conversations-bruce-reynolds/ |archivedate=20 April 2013 |df=dmy }} ==Career== After undertaking some petty crime and spending time in [[HMP Wormwood Scrubs]] and [[Borstal Prison|Borstal]] for theft (from which he escaped and was eventually caught and sent to Reading Prison), he spent six weeks of the required two years doing [[National Service]] in the [[British Army]], before running away to return to petty crime. Sentenced to three years in 1952 for breaking and entering, he was sent to the juvenile wing of [[HMP Wandsworth|Wandsworth Prison]] in London. He then graduated to jewellery theft from large country houses. In 1957 Reynolds was arrested, together with [[Terence Hogan|Terry Hogan]], for assault and robbery of a bookmaker returning from [[White City Greyhounds]] with £500.{{cite news|title=Alleged Assault On Bookmaker Two Men For Trial|journal= The Times|date=28 December 1957}} The police stated their belief that the intent of the cosh attack was grievous bodily harm and not robbery. Hogan was sentenced to 2½ years and Reynolds received a year longer.''Assault On Bookmaker'', The Times 17 January 1958 After spending time in [[HMP Wandsworth]] and [[HMP Durham]], on release in 1960 he then became an [[antiques]] dealer and thief.[http://www.crimeandinvestigation.co.uk/crime-files/great-train-robbery/crime.html The Great Train Robbery] He joined a gang with future best friend Harry Booth and future brother-in-law John Daly. Later on, he did some work with Jimmy White and met Buster Edwards at [[Charlie Richardson]]'s club. Richardson in turn introduced him to [[Gordon Goody]]. Having gained the moniker ''[[Napoleon]]'', in 1962 his gang stole £62,000 in a security van robbery at [[London Heathrow Airport]]. They then attempted to rob a [[Royal Mail]] train at [[Swindon]], which netted only £700. But Reynolds, now looking for his career-criminal defining moment, started planning his next train robbery over a period of three months. Reynolds organised a gang of 15 men to undertake the 1963 Great Train Robbery (which he later referred to as his "[[Sistine Chapel]] ceiling").{{cite news|journal=Newsday|title=Bruce Reynolds, 'Robbery' architect|author=Adam Bernstin, ''The Washington Post''|date=2 March 2013|page=A26}} After the theft, Reynolds spent six months in a mews house in [[South Kensington]] waiting for a false passport. He then travelled via [[Elstree Airfield]] to [[Ostend]], was then driven to [[Brussels Airport]], before flying with [[Sabena]] airlines to [[Mexico City]] via [[Toronto]].{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/live-chat-bruce-reynolds-7229082.html|title=Live chat with Bruce Reynolds|publisher=[[Evening Standard]]|date=8 August 2003|accessdate=28 February 2013}} Assuming the name ''Keith Clement Miller'', he was joined by his wife Frances, who changed her name to Angela, and son Nick. {{quote box |quote=I was beginning to see the thief as an artist ... Nothing could match the tension, excitement and sense of fulfillment. | source = Reynolds to the ''[[Daily Telegraph]]''{{Citation |author=Stephen Miller |publication-date=2013-03-01 |title=Leader of Notorious Train Heist |series=Remembrances |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |page=A9}} |align=right | width = 33% }} [[File:Ronnie-Biggs-celebrates-70th-birthday-1999.jpg|thumb|Reynolds ''(far right)'' at [[Ronnie Biggs]]' ''(far left)'' 70th birthday with their sons]] For Christmas 1964, the family were joined in [[Acapulco]] by fellow train robbers [[Buster Edwards]], who had not yet been caught, and treasurer [[Charlie Wilson (criminal)|Charlie Wilson]], who had escaped from [[HM Prison Birmingham|HMP Winson Green]]. Reynolds and his family later moved to [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], [[Canada]], where Wilson had settled with his family, but a proposed theft of [[Canadian dollar]]s was stopped due to [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] observation. Reynolds then moved to [[Vancouver]], before returning that summer to the [[South of France]]. By now running low on cash, he heard a similarly sized large robbery was being planned. The family returned to London, before then moving to [[Torquay]], [[Devon]]. Assuming the name ''Keith Hiller'', the family began a life of settling into Reynolds' former childhood holiday town, before he had the urge to make contact with his old friends back in London. The [[Metropolitan Police]] whilst watching the London criminal scene realised that Hiller was in fact Reynolds, and arrested him in Torquay on 9 November 1968.{{cite web|url=http://www.thisissouthdevon.co.uk/Great-Train-Robber-Bruce-Reynolds-run-ground/story-18278883-detail/story.html#axzz2MCsugqKA|title=How Great Train Robber Bruce Reynolds was run to ground in Torquay|author=Guy Henderson|publisher=Thisissouthdevon.co.uk|date=28 February 2013|accessdate=28 February 2013}} Offered a deal by the [[Director of Public Prosecutions (England and Wales)]] to plead guilty and avoid their pursuing his son, wife and family on further criminal charges, Reynolds agreed to plead guilty and was sentenced to 25 years. All of the Great Train robbers were held in maximum security in a specially built unit at [[HMP Durham]]. After making friends with both [[Charlie Richardson|Charlie]] and [[Eddie Richardson]] whilst in prison, Reynolds was released from [[HMP Maidstone]] in 1978.{{clarify|reason=if he was held at Durham how was he released from Maidstone?|date=December 2013}} After a failed attempt in the [[textile]] trade, he began trafficking and [[money laundering]] for many South London drugs gangs. Arrested for dealing [[amphetamine]]s, he was jailed in the 1980s for three years. ==Later life== [[File:Highgate Cemetery - East - Bruce Reynolds 02.jpg|thumb|Reynold's grave in [[Highgate Cemetery]].]] On release he gained a profile as a media "former criminal" figure, and acted as a consultant on the film ''[[Buster (film)|Buster]]'', with [[Larry Lamb (actor)|Larry Lamb]] portraying Reynolds. Reynolds then published his autobiography ''The Autobiography of a Thief'' (1995).{{cite book|title=The Autobiography of a Thief: The Man Behind The Great Train Robbery |author=Bruce Reynolds|year=1995|ISBN=0753510502}} In the book, Reynolds commented that the Great Train Robbery had proved a curse that followed him around, as after it no-one wanted to employ him either legally or illegally:{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/9900060/Bruce-Reynolds-the-Great-Train-Robbery-mastermind-dies.html|title=Bruce Reynolds, the Great Train Robbery mastermind, dies|publisher=Daily Telegraph|date=28 February 2013|accessdate=28 February 2013}} {{cquote|I became an old crook living on handouts from other old crooks.}} Having either spent or had removed by courts the monies that he gained through crime, by the 1990s Reynolds was living on [[income support]] in a flat in [[Croydon]], [[Greater London]], supplied by a charitable trust. Reynolds' wife predeceased him. He died on the afternoon of 28 February 2013 at the age of 81.{{cite news|title=Great Train Robber Bruce Reynolds dies aged 81|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21617926|accessdate=28 February 2013|publisher=BBC News|date=28 February 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/feb/28/bruce-reynolds|title=Obituary: Bruce Reynolds|publisher=The Guardian|date=28 February 2013|accessdate=28 February 2013}}[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/property/3360013/The-Train-Robber-House-On-the-spree-in-Torquay.html The "Train Robber House"] At the time of his death, Reynolds was working on'' The Great Train Robbery 50th Anniversary:1963–2013'', published by Mpress in July 2013. ==In popular culture== Multiple media properties and parodies have been produced about the Great Train Robbery [see [[Great Train Robbery (1963)#Details of the Great Train Robbery and the robbers|Details of the Great Train Robbery and the robbers]]]. Examples featuring Bruce Reynolds include: [[Horst Tappert#Filmography|''Die Gentlemen bitten zur Kasse'' (''The Gentleman Prefers Payment'', also known as ''Great British Train Robbery'')]] which aired on TV-Dreiteiler in 1966 and featured [[Horst Tappert]] as Reynolds, ''[[Robbery (1967 film)|Robbery]]'' (1967) with [[Stanley Baker]] as a character based upon Reynolds, and ''[[Buster (film)|Buster]]'' (1988) with [[Larry Lamb (actor)|Larry Lamb]] as Reynolds. In 2008, [[Shaun Micallef]] parodied Reynolds in Series 2, Episode 9 of an Australian Satirical Comedy News Series [[Newstopia]]. In 2012, Reynolds was portrayed in the television series ''[[Mrs Biggs]]'' by [[Jay Simpson (actor)|Jay Simpson]]. He was also the subject of the song "Have You Seen Bruce Richard Reynolds", originally by Nigel Denver and later covered by the UK band [[Alabama 3]]. Reynolds himself appears on the Alabama 3 version.{{Citation |title= Track List for Outlaw 2005 by Alabama 3|publication-place=Alabama 3 official site |url= http://www.alabama3.co.uk/en/general_articles/outlaw |accessdate=13 January 2015 }} On the day that [[Ronnie Biggs|Biggs]] died, 18 December 2013, the [[BBC]] broadcast the first of a two part series, ''[[The Great Train Robbery (2013 film)|The Great Train Robbery]]'', which provides a dramatisation of the events first from the criminals' perspective and then from that of the police. The program had already been scheduled for broadcast on that date.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/dec/18/ronnie-biggs-picks-moment-great-train-robbery |title=Ronnie Biggs picks his moment one last time |publisher=The Guardian |date=18 December 2013 |accessdate=23 December 2013 |last=Campbell |first=Duncan}} Bruce Reynolds was played by Welsh actor [[Luke Evans (actor)|Luke Evans]].{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/profiles/5glBpR157xrv3BztXK3NNDf/bruce-reynolds |title=Bruce Reynolds |publisher=[[BBC One]] |date=|accessdate=22 June 2017 |last=|first=}} ==References== {{Commons category|Bruce Reynolds}} {{reflist}} {{navigation great train robbery}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Reynolds, Bruce}} [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century English criminals]] [[Category:Bicycle messengers]] [[Category:British people convicted of theft]] [[Category:Criminals from London]] [[Category:Drug dealers]] [[Category:English autobiographers]] [[Category:English people convicted of assault]] [[Category:English prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:Fugitives wanted by the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Great Train Robbers]] [[Category:Great Train Robbery (1963)]] [[Category:People from Putney]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of England and Wales]]
