{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox military person | nationality = British | other_names = "Tony" | known_for = One of [[List of Allied airmen from the Great Escape|the "Great Escapers"]] | occupation = Aviator, farmer | honorific_prefix = | name = R. Anthony Bethell | honorific_suffix = | image = Royal Airforce Badge.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | nickname = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1922|4|9}} | birth_place = [[Dar-es-Salaam]], [[Tanganyika (territory)|Tangyanika territory]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2004|02|17|1922|4|9}} | death_place = Canada | placeofburial = Metis-sur-Mer, Quebec | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial_coordinates = | allegianc = United Kingdom | branch = [[Royal Air Force]] | serviceyears = 1941-1945, 1949-1955 | rank = [[Flight lieutenant]] | servicenumber = 120413 | unit = [[No. 268 Squadron RAF|No. 268 Squadron]]
[[No. 16 Squadron RAF|No. 16 Squadron]]
[[No. 145 Squadron RAF|No. 145 Squadron]] | commands = | battles = [[Second World War]] * [[European Theatre of World War II|European theatre]] ** [[Western Front (World War II)|Channel front]] ([[prisoner of war|POW]]) [[Cold War]] | battles_label = | awards = | memorials = | spouse = Lorna Bethell | relations = | laterwork = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | website = | module = }} '''Richard Anthony Bethell''', known as '''Anthony (or "Tony") Bethell''', (9 April 1922 - 17 February 2004) was born in Dar-es-Salaam in the British territory of [[Tanganyika (territory)|Tanganyika]]. He joined the [[Royal Air Force]] during the [[Second World War]]. After his [[North American P-51 Mustang|Mustang]] was shot down he was taken prisoner and held in the German [[prisoner of war]] camp [[Stalag Luft III]] at Sagan where he actively participated in the [[Stalag Luft III#The .22Great Escape.22|Great Escape]], being one of the 76 officers to break out and make some distance across enemy occupied territory before being recaptured. His name was not one of the 50 who were picked to be executed and he, with 25 others, went back into captivity. He retired from the RAF in 1955 and worked in financial services in Canada. He died in Canada in 2004. ==Early life== Bethell’s parents lived abroad serving with the British Colonial Services in East Africa and Gibraltar. Bethell was born on 9 April 1922 in [[Dar-es-Salaam]], then part of the British territory of [[Tanganyika (territory)|Tanganyika]]. He and his brother were boarders at Junior Kings School, Sturry, Kent and regularly sailed to Gibraltar to see their parents during school holidays. The Bethell family lived for some years in Gibraltar where his father was state treasurer, and only returned to England after his death. Bethell’s education was completed at [[Sherborne School]], where he attained the position of head boy. ==Service career== Joining the [[Royal Air Force]] as an [[Aircraftman|aircraftman 2nd class]] (service number 1314695) in February 1941, he completed pilot training in the USA in Georgia, Alabama and Florida. From there he was posted to a training unit at Hawarden before joining [[No. 268 Squadron RAF|No. 268 (Fighter) Squadron]] as a sergeant-pilot. He was commissioned as a [[pilot officer]] on 7 February 1942 with the RAF officer’s service number 120413{{London Gazette |issue=35547 |date=5 May 1942 |pages=1975–1976 }} and was promoted to [[flying officer]] on 1 October 1942.{{London Gazette |issue=35791 |date=17 November 1942 |page=5041 |supp=y}} Equipped with the [[North American P-51 Mustang]], 268 Squadron flew "rhubarbs" (low level sweeps) to attack enemy shipping off the Dutch coast and ground targets such as troop transports and military railway freight. On 26 November 1942, during a mission over the Netherlands he shot down a [[Messerschmitt Bf 109]] near [[Elburg]] and minutes later a [[Junkers Ju 52]] transport aircraft near [[Oldebroek]].Foreman (2005), p.208[[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|London National Archives]] document TNA, Air50/106/7 combat report (Pilot Officer R A Bethell, 268 Squadron, 26 November 1942) These were stated in his obituary to be the squadron's first successes and the first of hundreds to fall to Mustangs during the war. [[File:Mustang IIIs 19 Sqn RAF in flight April 1944.jpg|thumb|right|305px|Mustangs in RAF service.]] ==Capture== On 7 December 1942 Bethell was a member of a flight flying a low-level ground attack mission in the [[Alkmaar]] area of the Netherlands when his Mustang “V for Victor” (serial number ''AP212'') was hit by light anti-aircraft fire while only 20 feet off the ground. He crash landed and tried to evade German infantrymen searching for him by hiding in a dyke but was captured.Wilson (2000), p.31 Following interrogation at [[Dulag Luft]] he was sent to prison camp [[Stalag Luft III]] at Sagan.[http://www.lostaircraft.com/database.php?mode=viewentry&e=29480 Loss details of Mustang ''AP212'' at www.lostaircraft.com] During his time in captivity he was promoted flight lieutenant on 7 February 1944.{{London Gazette |issue=36396 |date=7 February 1944 |page=946 |supp=y}} ==The Great Escape== Bethell participated in "the [[Stalag Luft III escape|Great Escape]]" from [[Stalag Luft III]], he was actively involved in tunneling and hauling away the soil,Vance (2000), p.200 to build the tunnel in which two hundred men were to slip through a tunnel code named "Harry", which ran {{convert|28|ft}} below the ground and {{convert|365|ft}} outwards. Due to a calculation error, it surfaced just short of the tree-line which was supposed to give cover to the escapers. The 77th escaper was spotted by a guard around 5am and the alarm sounded. Bethell’s position during the escape was initially at "Leicester Square", the second staging point along the tunnel's length. His role was to pull 20 men through until relieved by escaper number 65 and then escape himself and take cover in the woods to await the next nine men before making good his escape.Carroll (2004), p.13 [[File:Model Stalag Luft III.jpg|thumb|right|305px|Model of Stalag Luft III prison camp.]] After pulling out 12 men, Bethell had to sit in his cramped underground space for 45 minutes until the next man arrived and explained that someone had got stuck and had to be pulled back and the tunnel repaired. Shortly after Bethell's group had cleared the tunnel into the woods there was a shot signalling that the escape had been discovered. They broke into twos and Bethell joined [[Les Long]] known to all as "Cookie",[http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/2194329/LONG,%20JAMES%20LESLIE%20ROBERT Commonwealth War Graves Commission casualty details for Flight Lieutenant James Leslie Robert Long RAFVR] hoping to cross the Czech border about 40 miles distant. Snow and flooding forced them to alter their route toward [[Frankfurt (Oder)|Frankfurt an der Oder]] where they hoped to hop on a freight train and escape to Sweden.Carroll (2004), p.160 They walked along a railway line, slept in a barn at night then started to travel in daylight but were captured at [[Bernau bei Berlin|Bernau]]. Long and Bethell were held in the ''[[Gestapo]]'' prison at [[Görlitz]] until Long was taken away and shot. Bethell was returned to the prison camp.Vance (2000), p.195 As the Russian [[Red Army]] approached Sagan in January 1945, Bethell was amongst the column of prisoners of war marched towards [[Lübeck]], arriving shortly before the end of the war. ==Later career== On release from wartime service he joined the trading company Gellatly Hankey in Africa working in the [[Khartoum]] and [[Addis Ababa]] area until boredom led him to rejoin the general duties branch of the [[Royal Air Force]] as a flight lieutenant on 7 December 1949.{{London Gazette |issue=38814 |date=17 January 1950 |page=283 |supp=y}} He became a navigator instructor and also served as personal assistant to [[George Pirie (RAF officer)|Air Chief Marshal Sir George Pirie]]. In 1953 he was posted to [[No. 145 Squadron RAF|No. 145 Squadron]] at [[Celle]] in Germany flying the [[de Havilland Vampire]], before becoming a flight commander on [[No. 16 Squadron RAF|No. 16 Squadron]], also operating Vampires from Celle close to the East German border. Bethell finally retired from the RAF in June 1955, after which he emigrated to Canada.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1456126/Flight-Lieutenant-Tony-Bethell.html ''The Daily Telegraph'' obituary, 6 March 2004] He was initially employed in the [[Brokerage firm|brokerage business]] in Montreal, he worked for Elican, a Belgian company and later joined the financial services industry. On retiring in the early 1990s he and his wife Lorna moved to a farm at [[Caledon, Ontario]], north of Toronto, where he spent much time on a [[John Deere]] tractor cutting fallow hayfields. ==Death== Tony Bethell died in Canada on 17 February 2004. ==Bibliography== *{{cite book|last=Foreman|first=John|year=2005|title=RAF Fighter Command Victory Claims, Part Two|publisher=Red Kite |location=Walton-on-Thames|isbn=0-9546201-5-1}} *{{cite book|last=Wilson|first=Philip|year=2000|title=The War Behind the Wire|publisher=Pen and Sword |location=London|asin=BOOKC3LKGI}} * {{cite book|author=Ted Barris|title=The Great Escape|publisher=Dundurn Publishing |year=2014|isbn=1459728440}} * {{cite book|author=Tim Carroll|title=The Great Escape from Stalag Luft III|publisher=Pocket Publishing |year=2005|isbn=1416505318}} * {{cite book|author=Simon Read |year=2012 |title=Human Game|publisher=Constable|isbn=978-1-4721-1262-0}} * {{cite book|author=Sean Feast|title=The Last of the 39-ers|publisher=Grub Street|year=2015|isbn=978-1909166158}} * {{cite book|author=Jonathan F Vance|title=A Gallant Company|publisher=Pacifica Military|year=2000|isbn=978-0-935-55347-5}} * {{cite book|author1=[[William Ash (pilot)|William Ash]]|author2=Brendan Foley|title=Under the Wire: The Wartime Memoir of a Spitfire Pilot, Legendary Escape Artist and 'cooler King'|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=quefAAAAMAAJ|year=2005|publisher=Bantam|isbn=978-0-593-05408-6}} * {{cite book|author=[[Paul Brickhill]]|title=The Great Escape|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KEWdJvOdZ2wC|year=2004|publisher=W.W. Norton & Company|isbn=978-0-393-32579-9}} * {{cite book|author=[[Alan Burgess]]|title=The Longest Tunnel: The True Story of World War II's Great Escape|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sy3t5zLmXrYC|year=1990|publisher=Naval Institute Press|isbn=978-1-59114-097-9}} * {{cite book|author=[[Albert P. Clark]]|title=33 Months as a POW in Stalag Luft III: A World War II Airman Tells His Story|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5f2fAAAAMAAJ|year=2005|publisher=Fulcrum Pub.|isbn=978-1-55591-536-0}} * {{cite book|author=Arthur A. Durand|title=Stalag Luft III: The Secret Story|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aQdSPgAACAAJ|date=1 January 1989|publisher=Patrick Stephens Limited|isbn=978-1-85260-248-2}} * {{cite book|author=William R Chorley|title=RAF Bomber Command Losses, Volume 2|publisher=Midland Counties|year=1993|isbn=0-950746703}} * {{cite book|author=Allen Andrews|title=Exemplary Justice|publisher=Harrap|year=1976|isbn=0-245-52775-3}} * {{cite book|author=W R Chorley|title=To See The Dawn Breaking|publisher=William Chorley|year=1981|isbn=0-245-52775-3}} *{{cite book | last = Vance| first = Jonathan F| authorlink = | coauthors = | title = A Gallant Company: The Men of the Great Escape | publisher = Pacifica Military History; (Mar 2001) | year = 2000| pages = 41 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-935-55347-5}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bethell, Anthony}} [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:2004 deaths]] [[Category:Participants in the Great Escape from Stalag Luft III]] [[Category:British military personnel of World War II]] [[Category:British World War II pilots]] [[Category:Royal Air Force officers]] [[Category:World War II prisoners of war held by Germany]] [[Category:Shot-down aviators]] [[Category:British stockbrokers]]
